Authors:
Robin van velzen, Gregory Allen Wahlert, Marc S.M. Sosef,
George E. Schatz, Porter P., II Lowry, Harvey Eugene Ballard, Kenneth
Jay Sytsma, Freek Bakker
Title:
Phylogeographic analysis of Rinorea (Violaceae) reveals
multiple recent dispersals from Africa to Madagascar
Keywords:
Africa, colonization, historical biogeography, Indian
Ocean, long-distance dispersal, Madagascar, Mozambique Channel,
Pliocene, Rinorea, trans-Atlantic dispersal
Abstract:
Madagascar is one of the worldÂ’s greatest biodiversity
hotspots, but the biogeographic origins of its flora are only partially
understood. We present a time-calibrated phylogeographic study of the
pantropical genus Rinorea (Violaceae) to reconstruct the directionality
and timing of dispersal in the genus, both globally and from Africa to
Madagascar. Phylogenetic analyses were conducted based on plastid and
nuclear DNA sequences using Bayesian algorithms, and divergence times
were estimated using a Bayesian relaxed molecular clock. Biogeographical
scenarios and potential ancestral areas were investigated using
statistical dispersal-vicariance analysis (S-DIVA) and the
dispersal-extinction-cladogenesis (DEC) method. Our analyses suggest
that Rinorea originated in South America and reached Africa in the
Oligocene, probably via trans-Atlantic dispersal. In Africa, the genus
has radiated since the early Miocene and dispersed to Asia in the lower
or middle Miocene. Members of African Rinorea clades colonized
Madagascar five times independently in the Pliocene or Pleistocene.
These results suggest that, at least for plants, Madagascar has been
much less isolated through time than has previously been assumed. We
speculate that climatic convergence between East Africa and Madagascar
since the late Miocene may have facilitated the establishment of plant
populations after dispersal from Africa to Madagascar.
